channel.title: Reflecting fields in RS client
channel.description:
I'm working on a reflection based bot.
I've written a loader, signlink interface, and a simple reflection explorer.
I have a few questions.
1. How can I get non-static fields from the reflection explorer? I understand I need to pass in an instance of the class to get() but how can I find out if the class has been loaded? Currently I use this:
[code=java] Class<?> slClass = rsClassLoader.loadRSClass(text); Field[] cVars = slClass.getFields(); Method[] cMethods = slClass.getDeclaredMethods();[/code]
(text is a string with the name of the class)
and then this to add it to a listbox: [code=java]refListModel.addElement(f.toString() + " = " + f.get(null));[/code]
but it only works on static fields because I am passing in null.
And my 2nd question...
How can I find out which fields to reflect? Like which ones represent stats, tiles, inventory, etc. This may become easier once I have my reflection explorer working better. It's just hard to weed through pages and pages of "kq.z" and "jg.m".
I have a working 563 deob (have you seen the code that decompilers generate? 0xFFFFFFFFL >> 0xFFFFFFFFL >> anInt2347294, goto statements that don't even exist in Java and crazy stuff like that lol) if that would help at all in finding what to reflect.
So thanks for reading and try to halp plox. ;)
Tekk

item.title: Reflecting fields in RS client
item.dc:creator: @Tekk123 Tekk
item.description:
@Tekk123 wrote:

Thanks D e n v e r.

Also, since there was a client update today (I think…), we’ll see how well the few hooks I’ve done hold up.[br][br][size=1]Posted on: September 23, 2009, 05:14:01 pm[/size][hr]My baseY is ALREADY BROKEN.

Welcome to the world of updaters, right?

Edit: No it’s not, I just fail at using my own updater.

Read full topic

item.title: Reflecting fields in RS client
item.dc:creator: @D_e_n_v_e_r D e n v e r
item.description:
@D_e_n_v_e_r wrote:

[quote=“Tekk123, post:1, topic:303315”]I’m working on a reflection based bot.

I’ve written a loader, signlink interface, and a simple reflection explorer.

I have a few questions.

  1. How can I get non-static fields from the reflection explorer? I understand I need to pass in an instance of the class to get() but how can I find out if the class has been loaded? Currently I use this:

Class<?> slClass = rsClassLoader.loadRSClass(text); Field[] cVars = slClass.getFields(); Method[] cMethods = slClass.getDeclaredMethods();

(text is a string with the name of the class)

and then this to add it to a listbox:

refListModel.addElement(f.toString() + " = " + f.get(null));

but it only works on static fields because I am passing in null.

And my 2nd question…

How can I find out which fields to reflect? Like which ones represent stats, tiles, inventory, etc. This may become easier once I have my reflection explorer working better. It’s just hard to weed through pages and pages of “kq.z” and “jg.m”.

I have a working 563 deob (have you seen the code that decompilers generate? 0xFFFFFFFFL >> 0xFFFFFFFFL >> anInt2347294, goto statements that don’t even exist in Java and crazy stuff like that lol) if that would help at all in finding what to reflect.

So thanks for reading and try to halp plox.

Tekk[/quote]
1- to reflect private fields use getDeclaredFields instead of getFields():

Field[] cVars = slClass.getDeclaredFields();

2- you have no problem reflecting statics fields that is a field.get(null) , but to reflect a non-static field (not a client field), you will have to reflect its value from an object that carries an instance of it, for example lets say you want to to get the name of your player.
To do that, you’d have to reflect the getPlayerName non-static from the MyPlayer static field wich will look like:

Object myPlayer = myPlayerField.get(null); //since its static String myPlayerName = playerNameField.getString(myPlayer)// will get a player's name from //myPlayer's object wich will in turn , return my player's name //and since its a name (String), that is why we've used the getString(Object o) function.

3-To know what fields are responsible for what, you can just look @ previous Updaters output and learn how to detect and maintain them with some bytecode editor library such as BCEL,and write an updater for them, you can thank the old people who initially discovered them by hardwork,
other than that, to discover some new fields, just read deobs to find out some methods that use fields and that can be useful to know whats the purpose of the field, and/or use a reflection explorer as you mentioned to detect variations during game play, but there will be thousands of them, so try customizing the explorer and limit the fields ammount.

Hope that helped ^^

Read full topic

item.title: Reflecting fields in RS client
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Tekk123:

Is there a reflection modifier that denotes that the field is an array?

Yes, there is.
Take a look at “public String getArray()” in:
http://cherokeeengine.svn.sourceforge.net/viewvc/cherokeeengine/src/com/cherokee/utils/FieldObject.java?view=markup
It lists out all of the types of arrays and such, the whole file might be of some help to you actually.

Read full topic

item.title: Reflecting fields in RS client
item.dc:creator: @Tekk123 Tekk
item.description:
@Tekk123 wrote:

oksuper_:

Do you by any chance know what an ‘updater’ is?

Had a general idea but did not know how you made one with reflection. I’ll figure it out though,

oksuper_:

Originally it actually was supposed to update a bot, now they are written for no reason other than epeen.

oksuper_:

Their duty is to locate things via patterns inside the client’s bytecode. What do they locate? Things like the class which represents a player, the field that holds the various client state array, etc. Finding these through a ‘debugger’ (I guess you could apply that term here) using reflection is like what dafan did with RuneGrail or whatever, It is NOT a good way to go about locating these things.

Ok, I won’t do that. So the updater is a separate program from the bot, which generates a report, which you then integrate into the bot.

oksuper_:

[quote]I have a working 563 deob (have you seen the code that decompilers generate? 0xFFFFFFFFL >> 0xFFFFFFFFL >> anInt2347294, goto statements that don’t even exist in Java and crazy stuff like that lol) if that would help at all in finding what to reflect.

goto’s… most definitely from obfuscation. But you claim it’s a ‘deob’?[/quote]

Well I used a better deobfuscator and the gotos went away, but there is still a lot of random variables/unused code.[br][br][size=1]Posted on: September 21, 2009, 07:22:45 pm[/size][hr]Well I’ve written a basic updater that hooks BaseX, BaseY and Run Energy. Now I need to hook the inventory and levels, which I think would be stored in an array.

I have a method to search all classes for integer fields, then find ones that match a pattern, but how would I write a method to loop through all of the client’s int arrays and look for levels/item IDs? Is there a reflection modifier that denotes that the field is an array?

Read full topic

item.title: Reflecting fields in RS client
item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

Do you by any chance know what an ‘updater’ is? Originally it actually was supposed to update a bot, now they are written for no reason other than epeen. Their duty is to locate things via patterns inside the client’s bytecode. What do they locate? Things like the class which represents a player, the field that holds the various client state array, etc. Finding these through a ‘debugger’ (I guess you could apply that term here) using reflection is like what dafan did with RuneGrail or whatever, It is NOT a good way to go about locating these things.

I have a working 563 deob (have you seen the code that decompilers generate? 0xFFFFFFFFL >> 0xFFFFFFFFL >> anInt2347294, goto statements that don't even exist in Java and crazy stuff like that lol) if that would help at all in finding what to reflect.
goto's... most definitely from obfuscation. But you claim it's a 'deob'?

Read full topic

item.title: Reflecting fields in RS client
item.dc:creator: @Tekk123 Tekk
item.description:
@Tekk123 wrote:

I’m thinking of some sort of system that could build a “map” of which classes refer to which…like start at “client”, find which classes it creates static instances of, then get the fields of those, then get which classes those create static instances of…and repeat until you have the client mapped out.

Read full topic

item.title: Reflecting fields in RS client
item.dc:creator: @the_bank the bank
item.description:
@the_bank wrote:

[quote=“Tekk123, post:7, topic:303315”][quote author=the bank link=topic=399640.msg2964235#msg2964235 date=1253454417]

first question : find a static field which of the type you want to get the field from and put it as the argument,
second : make yourself and updater and look for patterns which will show you which fields are which

So, for the first question…

If I am inspecting class gf, gf.j is a static field of class gf, and I want to find the non-static fields, I can just say field.get(class.getField(“j”)); right?

And for the second, is there any way reflection updaters are different than BCEL ones (other than the fact that they use different ways to update)? I’ve only seen tutorials for BCEL updaters here.

Thanks for the help.
[/quote]No. Not correct.

Alright, lets see here…

Class Class1:
public int a;
public static int b = 2;

Class Class2:
public static Class1 c = new Class1();

To get the field “b” :
f.get(null);

To get the field “a” relative to the instance of Class1 in Class2 :
Object o = f2.get(null); //where f2 is the field “c” in Class2
f.get(f2); //where f is the field “a”

I might be off on a few things, it has been awhile, but that is the basic idea.

So first I need to find which classes declare instances of the ones I want to get the variables from.[/quote]static instances*

And yes, but remember this, fields which aren’t static can hold different values depending on instance (don’t know a better way to put it). For example:

Class1 a = new Class1();
Class1 b = new Class1();

a.a = 1;
b.a = 47;

Read full topic

item.description:
@the_bank wrote:

[quote=“Tekk123, post:4, topic:303315”][quote author=Nueb35 link=topic=399640.msg2963885#msg2963885 date=1253428096]
first question : find a static field which of the type you want to get the field from and put it as the argument,
second : make yourself and updater and look for patterns which will show you which fields are which
[/quote]

So, for the first question…

If I am inspecting class gf, gf.j is a static field of class gf, and I want to find the non-static fields, I can just say field.get(class.getField(“j”)); right?

And for the second, is there any way reflection updaters are different than BCEL ones (other than the fact that they use different ways to update)? I’ve only seen tutorials for BCEL updaters here.

Thanks for the help.[/quote]No. Not correct.

Alright, lets see here…

Class Class1:
public int a;
public static int b = 2;

Class Class2:
public static Class1 c = new Class1();

To get the field “b” :
f.get(null);

To get the field “a” relative to the instance of Class1 in Class2 :
Object o = f2.get(null); //where f2 is the field “c” in Class2
f.get(f2); //where f is the field “a”

I might be off on a few things, it has been awhile, but that is the basic idea.

item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

If you want to get all of the instances of a class: you could use instrumenation / byte code editing to add itself to a list in the constructor. Make sure you use WeakRefrences.

Of course this would defeat the purpose of reflecting it.

My (useless) 2 cents.

item.title: Reflecting fields in RS client
item.dc:creator: @Tekk123 Tekk
item.description:
@Tekk123 wrote:

I’m working on a reflection based bot.

I’ve written a loader, signlink interface, and a simple reflection explorer.

I have a few questions.

  1. How can I get non-static fields from the reflection explorer? I understand I need to pass in an instance of the class to get() but how can I find out if the class has been loaded? Currently I use this:

Class<?> slClass = rsClassLoader.loadRSClass(text); Field[] cVars = slClass.getFields(); Method[] cMethods = slClass.getDeclaredMethods();

(text is a string with the name of the class)

and then this to add it to a listbox:

refListModel.addElement(f.toString() + " = " + f.get(null));

but it only works on static fields because I am passing in null.

And my 2nd question…

How can I find out which fields to reflect? Like which ones represent stats, tiles, inventory, etc. This may become easier once I have my reflection explorer working better. It’s just hard to weed through pages and pages of “kq.z” and “jg.m”.

I have a working 563 deob (have you seen the code that decompilers generate? 0xFFFFFFFFL >> 0xFFFFFFFFL >> anInt2347294, goto statements that don’t even exist in Java and crazy stuff like that lol) if that would help at all in finding what to reflect.

So thanks for reading and try to halp plox.

Tekk

Read full topic
